title: Help regarding restoring history from corrupted places.sqlite file.
content:
Hello Community,

About a month ago Firefox had disabled all of my add-ons, as well as broken all of the icons for my bookmarks. I later learned that this problem had also completely cleared my browser history. I saw that the computer had reset my places.sqlite file, and that I had a new "places.sqlite.corrupt" file. I tried renaming that corrupted file to get back my old history, as well as refreshing Firefox, but neither of these strategies seemed to have worked. Does anyone have a way of restoring my data from my old places.sqlite file? Thanks!

title: No Google Maps
content: I know this has been referred to in other topics but they appear they have been closed without a resolution from Firefox. This problem is one of the many reasons users should not take the updates that Firefox forces upon you: too many problems incorporated which take too long to fix. It took me a long while to find a working method which Firefox wouldn't broadcast, but I got there in the end. Google just doesn't update, it broadcast the changes well in advance allowing developers to adapt before the roll out. Developers who don't work for Firefox that is! I had stopped updates as they make more problems than they fix, but had to try the latest as Google maps stopped working: All I get is a blank webpage with nothing showing. Others have suggested a plugin etc. etc. etc., but this does not solve the fact that other browser don't have this problem and neither does Firefox! What! You read this right! version 52.0 works without a hitch with Google maps, so a way of getting Firefox to work is to revert to a previous version which doesn't have the dodgy embedded code. So why exactly are we waiting for an update for something that has worked in the past but has now stopped because the developers either don't know how to fix it or can't be bothered. Firefox are clearly showing they are not coping with updates as well as the competition. I use the term loosely, as Firefox appear to have given up entirely!

title: CMD+Mouse Wheel to Zoom in Firefox for macOS [Fix Firefox 109.0 Intentional Bug]
content:
Firefox 109.0 for macOS introduced an intentional bug that disables the popular highly useful zoom in/out using cmd+mouse wheel. Mozilla claims that this engineered bug "avoids accidental zooming and matches the behavior of other web browsers on macOS." However, it causes severe trouble for productivity users and the large user community who use a mouse and keyboard.

Could you please let me know how the highly popular and practical zoom in/out using cmd+mouse wheel could be re-enabled in Firefox 109.0?

Also, I would like to ask Mozilla to respect user decisions and let them choose whether they prefer to disable Ctrl or Cmd + trackpad or mouse wheel (scrolls the page instead of zooming) or use it.

Thanks
creator: AYD

title: seguridad
content:
texto en negritaNO ME DEJA DESCARGAR MI CERTIFICADO ELECTRÓNICO POR SEGURIDAD Advertencia: riesgo potencial de seguridad a continuación

Firefox ha detectado una posible amenaza de seguridad y no ha cargado www.sede.fnmt.gob.es. Si visita este sitio, los atacantes podrían intentar robar información como sus contraseñas, correos electrónicos o detalles de su tarjeta de crédito.

¿Qué puede hacer al respecto?

El problema está probablemente en el sitio web, y no hay nada que pueda hacer para resolverlo.

Si está en una red corporativa o utilizando un antivirus, puede ponerse en contacto con el equipo de asistencia para obtener ayuda. También puede notificar el problema al administrador del sitio web.

Más información…

Alguien podría estar tratando de suplantar el sitio y usted no debería continuar.

Los sitios web prueban su identidad mediante certificados. Firefox no confía en www.sede.fnmt.gob.es porque su emisor del certificado es desconocido, el certificado es autofirmado o el servidor no está enviando los certificados intermediarios correctos.

Código de error: SEC_ERROR_UNKNOWN_ISSUER

Ver certificado

title: Bringing back previewing PDFs inline without downloading the file*
content:
I've recently made the switch to Firefox last month and was trying to view a PDF embedded inline on a site (Canvas, commonly used in schools and universities), but kept getting a blank box. I had to download the file to view it- I couldn't just preview it. I'm aware that "previewing" or "opening" PDFs without choosing to save them actually just saved them to a temp folder locally which the system would delete eventually on its own, and this new change from version 98+ supposedly "optimizes" the download process because "Firefox no longer saves files to a temporary folder because of the downsides to saving files in a location that is hard to discover."

Downsides? What downsides???

Removing that feature quite literally does the opposite of optimizing when the average user, and in fact all users, benefit from being able to preview PDFs by keeping them in a temp folder. If we wanted to download something, we would choose to save the file where we want it to be. You're literally presenting "save file" and "open file" as if they're two different choices, when "open file" is really just "save file, and then we open it for you, and you have to manually delete it yourself later!". This is objectively a downgrade in every way. There's no optimization here. I realize that me as just one person asking for this will fall on deaf ears, but I have to try. Please bring back the option to preview files by automatically saving them to a temp folder without me having to set my default download folder for ALL files as a temp folder.

Please think about the situation of someone like a teacher who needs to mark 40 students' PDF homework submissions in Canvas, which lets you quickly change between inline previews within the site of each PDF with its grading UI on the side, making it convenient for them to grade. With this change they either have to download 40 PDFs onto their hard drive, or go back to using Chrome, where the PDF.js extension (the very same PDF viewer that's built into Firefox and backed by Mozilla?!) actually will let them preview the temp files, no problem. And I'm not even teaching right now, I'm just a student who fell into this rabbit hole because I wanted to do my homework and all the PDFs are blank boxes in Firefox while they appear just fine on Chrome.

I really want to be using Firefox full time. I really do! But by taking away this very useful feature, you're literally forcing my hand into using Chrome again.

title: Webcam/Mic Access on Doxy
content:
I'm using MacOS Ventura 13.1; Firefox 199.0 on a 2018 MacBook Pro Note: Doxy advises Mac users not to use Safari; but to use Firefox or Chrome instead.

I tried logging into a regularly scheduled meeting today and in the waiting room, Doxy told me (via a dinosaur) that it had no access to my webcam. In the past, I have not had this situation. I did a number of things on my Mac (restarting the app, restarting the machine, resetting my SMC at restart) and none of them seemed to work. I had already checked that my OS gave Firefox access to the camera and mic, and Firefox's settings gave access to doxy.me. After a number of tries, I was finally able to get into the meeting albeit 35 minutes late.

As soon as it ended I retried getting in and found that access to the camera and mic were again disabled. In the Permissions Tab in Page Info, the camera and mic were set to "Use Default", which I assumed was to allow access. I checked the "Allow" button for both, reloaded the page and the camera light came on. I changed the permissions back to "Use default"; quit and started up again. I got the no access message. I reloaded the page and part, but not all, of the video feed appeared. I checked the Permissions and they were set as I had left them. Clicking "Allow" and reloading the page got the video back. However, this problem recurs if I quit and restart Firefox.

While I was trying to get into my meeting, I tried Chrome and got the camera with a line through it. So, I thought that it might be a MacOS problem. However, after getting into the meeting on Firefox, I went back and found a similar control in Chrome that toggles camera and mic in the active window. I reset those, and have not had the access problem since.

P.S. I notice that Settings has only "Allow" and "Block" as permission options for the camera and mic, but the permissions tab in Page Info has "Always Ask" in addition to "Allow" and "Block". In this instance, I was never asked when I chose "Always Ask", and the camera did not go on.

I am also going to post this in the Apple Support Community and with Doxy, as I am not convinced that there is not some OS/application or Doxy communication problem given I had similar situations with Chrome and Firefox. I DO NOT want to use Chrome (or any other Google product, for that matter), and I have a workaround, but it used to work without the workaround.
